title: WiFi Standards - 802.11ac, 802.11ax, 802.11be
description: Master modern WiFi protocols: 802.11ac (WiFi 5), 802.11ax (WiFi 6), and 802.11be (WiFi 7). Understand specifications, features, and real-world deployment.
starterCode:
# WiFi STANDARDS EXERCISE
# Deploy modern WiFi with 802.11ac/ax/be standards

## SCENARIO: Enterprise WiFi Migration
## - Organization: Campus upgrading from 802.11ac to 802.11ax
## - Challenge: Select right standard for performance needs
## - Current: WiFi 5 (802.11ac, 2013 standard)
## - Goal: Transition to WiFi 6 (802.11ax, 2019)

## PART 1: 802.11AC (WiFi 5)
## Q1: 802.11ac overview:
##     Standard year: _______ (2013)
##     Marketing name: _______ (WiFi 5)
##     Frequency: _______ (5 GHz only, no 2.4 GHz)
##     Technology: _______ (MIMO, beamforming)
##     Maximum speed: _______ (1.3 Gbps theoretical)

## Q2: 802.11ac features:
##     Frequency bands:
##     - 5 GHz only: _______ (no backward compat with 2.4 GHz)
##     - Channels: _______ (20, 40, 80 MHz wide)
##     - Max width: _______ (80 MHz per stream)
##     
##     Bandwidth improvements:
##     - 802.11n: 600 Mbps (40 MHz)
##     - 802.11ac: _______ (1.3 Gbps, 80 MHz)

## Q3: MIMO and antennas:
##     Spatial streams (802.11ac):
##     - Maximum: _______ (8 spatial streams)
##     - Typical AP: _______ (4-8 antennas)
##     - Typical client: _______ (2-4 antennas)
##     
##     Formula:
##     - 802.11ac speed = Bandwidth × Modulation × Streams
##     - 80 MHz × 1 × 8 = _______ (1.3 Gbps)

## Q4: Beamforming in 802.11ac:
##     Purpose: _______ (focus signal toward client)
##     Benefits:
##     - Range: _______ (extends effective range)
##     - Throughput: _______ (improves speed)
##     - Signal: _______ (better quality)
##     
##     Traditional:
##     - Omnidirectional: Spreads all directions
##     - Efficiency: Wasted energy
##     
##     Beamforming:
##     - Directional: _______ (focused beam)
##     - Efficiency: _______ (concentrated power)

## Q5: 802.11ac deployment considerations:
##     5 GHz only:
##     - Advantage: _______ (less congestion than 2.4 GHz)
##     - Disadvantage: _______ (shorter range, walls)
##     
##     Range issues:
##     - Distance: ~100 feet (vs 150+ for 802.11n)
##     - Solution: _______ (more APs, better placement)
##     
##     Device support:
##     - Requirement: _______ (5 GHz capable)
##     - Older devices: _______ (won't work, need 11n)

## PART 2: 802.11AX (WiFi 6)
## Q6: 802.11ax overview:
##     Standard year: _______ (2019, finalized 2021)
##     Marketing name: _______ (WiFi 6)
##     Frequency: _______ (2.4 GHz AND 5 GHz, dual-band)
##     Technology: _______ (MIMO, MU-MIMO, OFDMA)
##     Maximum speed: _______ (9.6 Gbps theoretical)

## Q7: Major 802.11ax improvements:
##     Speed improvement:
##     - 802.11ac: 1.3 Gbps
##     - 802.11ax: _______ (9.6 Gbps, 7.4x faster)
##     - Real-world: _______ (2-4 Gbps typical)
##     
##     Technology gains:
##     - OFDMA: _______ (divide channel into sub-channels)
##     - MU-MIMO: _______ (multiple users simultaneously)
##     - Spatial streams: _______ (up to 8+)

## Q8: OFDMA (Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access):
##     Purpose: _______ (efficient spectrum utilization)
##     
##     Traditional (802.11ac):
##     - Channel: One client uses entire 80 MHz
##     - Others: Wait for turn
##     - Efficiency: _______ (poor if many clients)
##     
##     OFDMA (802.11ax):
##     - Channel: _______ (divided into sub-channels)
##     - Clients: _______ (multiple get portions simultaneously)
##     - Efficiency: _______ (better spectrum usage)

## Q9: MU-MIMO in 802.11ax:
##     Multi-user MIMO:
##     - 802.11ac limit: _______ (one client at a time)
##     - 802.11ax: _______ (multiple clients simultaneously)
##     - Result: _______ (higher total throughput)
##     
##     Example:
##     - Scenario: 4 clients downloading
##     - 802.11ac: Serve one client at 325 Mbps each (rotates)
##     - 802.11ax: _______ (all 4 simultaneously, shared)

## Q10: Target Wait Time (TWT):
##      Purpose: _______ (allow devices to sleep more)
##      
##      Traditional WiFi:
##      - Client: Always listening for packets
##      - Power: _______ (battery drains fast)
##      - Latency: Low
##      
##      TWT (802.11ax):
##      - Scheduling: _______ (AP tells when to wake)
##      - Power: _______ (dramatic battery savings)
##      - Latency: _______ (slight increase)

## Q11: Dual-band advantage (802.11ax):
##      802.11ac (5 GHz only):
##      - Old device (802.11g): _______ (won't connect)
##      - Solution: _______ (separate AP needed)
##      
##      802.11ax (2.4 + 5 GHz):
##      - Old device (802.11g): _______ (connects at 2.4 GHz)
##      - New device (WiFi 6): _______ (connects at 5 GHz)
##      - Benefit: _______ (one AP supports all)

## Q12: 802.11ax channel widths:
##      5 GHz channels:
##      - 20 MHz: _______ (baseline)
##      - 40 MHz: _______ (two 20 MHz combined)
##      - 80 MHz: _______ (four 20 MHz combined)
##      - 160 MHz: _______ (eight 20 MHz combined)
##      
##      Wider channels:
##      - Benefit: _______ (higher throughput)
##      - Drawback: _______ (fewer total channels available)

## PART 3: 802.11BE (WiFi 7)
## Q13: 802.11be overview:
##     Standard year: _______ (2024, emerging)
##     Marketing name: _______ (WiFi 7)
##     Frequency: _______ (2.4 GHz, 5 GHz, AND 6 GHz)
##     Technology: _______ (higher MIMO, wider channels)
##     Maximum speed: _______ (46 Gbps theoretical)

## Q14: 802.11be improvements:
##     Speed progression:
##     - 802.11ac: 1.3 Gbps
##     - 802.11ax: 9.6 Gbps
##     - 802.11be: _______ (46 Gbps, 4.8x faster than 11ax)
##     
##     New features:
##     - 6 GHz support: _______ (additional spectrum)
##     - Wider channels: _______ (up to 320 MHz)
##     - Spatial streams: _______ (12+ possible)

## Q15: 6 GHz spectrum (802.11be):
##      New band: _______ (6 GHz frequency range)
##      Channels: _______ (many more than 5 GHz)
##      Benefits:
##      - Congestion: _______ (very low, new band)
##      - Speed: _______ (maximum theoretical capacity)
##      - Devices: _______ (WiFi 6E, WiFi 7 only)
##      
##      Timeline:
##      - FCC approval: 2020
##      - Devices available: _______ (2021+)

## Q16: Multi-link operation (802.11be):
##      Purpose: _______ (simultaneously use multiple bands)
##      
##      Example:
##      - Device connected: 5 GHz + 6 GHz simultaneously
##      - Benefit: _______ (combined throughput)
##      - Use: _______ (video, large file transfer)

## PART 4: DEPLOYMENT DECISIONS
## Q17: Choosing WiFi standard:
##      Scenario A - Budget deployment:
##      - Budget: $15,000, 5,000 sq ft office
##      - Standard: _______ (802.11n or 11ac)
##      - Reason: _______ (cost-effective, adequate)
##      
##      Scenario B - High-performance campus:
##      - Requirement: 1+ Gbps per user
##      - Devices: Mix old and new
##      - Standard: _______ (802.11ax for flexibility)

## Q18: 802.11ax vs 802.11ac comparison:
##      Metric: Speed
##      - 802.11ac: _______ (1.3 Gbps theoretical)
##      - 802.11ax: _______ (9.6 Gbps theoretical)
##      
##      Metric: Bands
##      - 802.11ac: _______ (5 GHz only)
##      - 802.11ax: _______ (2.4 + 5 GHz)
##      
##      Metric: MU-MIMO
##      - 802.11ac: _______ (one client at time)
##      - 802.11ax: _______ (multiple simultaneously)

## Q19: Migration path:
##      Old network (802.11n): 2009 standard
##      Current (802.11ac): 2013 standard
##      New (802.11ax): 2019 standard
##      Future (802.11be): 2024+ standard
##      
##      Timeline:
##      - Keep 11ac: _______ (5+ year lifespan)
##      - Upgrade to 11ax: _______ (when budget allows)
##      - Later to 11be: _______ (when devices available)

## Q20: Real-world expectations:
##      Theoretical vs real:
##      - 802.11ac theoretical: 1.3 Gbps
##      - 802.11ac real: _______ (400-600 Mbps typical)
##      - Factor: _______ (overhead, collisions, distance)
##      
##      802.11ax real:
##      - Theoretical: 9.6 Gbps
##      - Real: _______ (2-3 Gbps typical)
##      - Benefit: _______ (better than 11ac, multiple users)

## PART 5: DEPLOYMENT SCENARIOS
## Q21: Stadium WiFi deployment:
##      Challenge: 50,000 concurrent users
##      
##      Solution:
##      - Standard: _______ (802.11ax minimum)
##      - AP density: _______ (very high, 1 per 1000 sq ft)
##      - Bands: _______ (all three: 2.4/5/6 GHz)
##      - Controller: _______ (centralized management)

## Q22: Healthcare facility WiFi:
##      Requirements:
##      - Reliability: _______ (critical, medical devices)
##      - Latency: _______ (low, real-time requirements)
##      - Coverage: _______ (uninterrupted)
##      
##      Standard: 802.11ax with redundancy
##      - Dual APs: Every location
##      - Handoff: _______ (smooth, low latency)

## Q23: Home WiFi decision:
##      Family has:
##      - 4K TV (WiFi 5 capable)
##      - Laptops (WiFi 6 capable)
##      - Smart home (WiFi 4)
##      - Budget: $150
##      
##      Recommendation: _______ (WiFi 6 router)
##      - Reason: _______ (supports all, future-proof)

## Q24: Enterprise network upgrade:
##      Current: 50 802.11ac APs, 2000 devices
##      
##      Upgrade plan:
##      - Phase 1 (Year 1): _______ (add WiFi 6 in core areas)
##      - Phase 2 (Year 2): _______ (replace all with 11ax)
##      - Cost: _______ ($150K+ equipment/install)

## PART 6: TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS
## Q25: Data rates summary:
##      802.11n: _______ (600 Mbps, 40 MHz)
##      802.11ac: _______ (1.3 Gbps, 80 MHz)
##      802.11ax: _______ (9.6 Gbps, 160 MHz)
##      802.11be: _______ (46 Gbps, 320 MHz)

## Q26: Spectrum efficiency:
##      Modulation progression:
##      - BPSK (802.11b): _______ (1 bit per symbol)
##      - 16-QAM (802.11a): _______ (4 bits per symbol)
##      - 256-QAM (802.11ac): _______ (8 bits per symbol)
##      - 1024-QAM (802.11ax): _______ (10 bits per symbol)

## Q27: Backward compatibility chain:
##      Device types:
##      - 802.11a: _______ (connects to 5 GHz only)
##      - 802.11n: _______ (connects 2.4/5 GHz)
##      - 802.11ac: _______ (connects 5 GHz only, faster)
##      - 802.11ax: _______ (connects all bands)

## Q28: Planning checklist:
##      Before deployment decide:
##      - Standard: _______ (select 11ax or 11be)
##      - Coverage: _______ (AP count for area)
##      - Bands: _______ (2.4/5/6 GHz mix)
##      - Channels: _______ (plan non-overlapping)
##      - PoE budget: _______ (power for APs)
##      - Controller: _______ (centralized or standalone)
solution:
# WiFi STANDARDS SOLUTION

## PART 1: 802.11AC (WiFi 5)

### 802.11ac Overview

**Standard year**: **2013** ✓
**Marketing name**: **WIFI 5** ✓
**Frequency**: **5 GHZ ONLY, NO 2.4 GHZ** ✓
**Technology**: **MIMO, BEAMFORMING** ✓
**Maximum speed**: **1.3 GBPS THEORETICAL** ✓

### 802.11ac Features

**Frequency bands**:
- 5 GHz only: **NO BACKWARD COMPAT WITH 2.4 GHZ** ✓
- Channels: **20, 40, 80 MHZ WIDE** ✓
- Max width: **80 MHZ PER STREAM** ✓

**Bandwidth improvements**:
- 802.11n: 600 Mbps (40 MHz)
- 802.11ac: **1.3 GBPS, 80 MHZ** ✓

### MIMO and Antennas

**Spatial streams** (802.11ac):
- Maximum: **8 SPATIAL STREAMS** ✓
- Typical AP: **4-8 ANTENNAS** ✓
- Typical client: **2-4 ANTENNAS** ✓

**Formula**:
- 802.11ac speed = Bandwidth × Modulation × Streams
- 80 MHz × 1 × 8 = **1.3 GBPS** ✓

### Beamforming in 802.11ac

**Purpose**: **FOCUS SIGNAL TOWARD CLIENT** ✓
**Benefits**:
- Range: **EXTENDS EFFECTIVE RANGE** ✓
- Throughput: **IMPROVES SPEED** ✓
- Signal: **BETTER QUALITY** ✓

**Traditional**:
- Omnidirectional: Spreads all directions
- Efficiency: Wasted energy

**Beamforming**:
- Directional: **FOCUSED BEAM** ✓
- Efficiency: **CONCENTRATED POWER** ✓

### 802.11ac Deployment Considerations

**5 GHz only**:
- Advantage: **LESS CONGESTION THAN 2.4 GHZ** ✓
- Disadvantage: **SHORTER RANGE, WALLS** ⚠️

**Range issues**:
- Distance: ~100 feet (vs 150+ for 802.11n)
- Solution: **MORE APS, BETTER PLACEMENT** ✓

**Device support**:
- Requirement: **5 GHZ CAPABLE** ✓
- Older devices: **WON'T WORK, NEED 11N** ⚠️

## PART 2: 802.11AX (WiFi 6)

### 802.11ax Overview

**Standard year**: **2019, FINALIZED 2021** ✓
**Marketing name**: **WIFI 6** ✓
**Frequency**: **2.4 GHZ AND 5 GHZ, DUAL-BAND** ✓
**Technology**: **MIMO, MU-MIMO, OFDMA** ✓
**Maximum speed**: **9.6 GBPS THEORETICAL** ✓

### Major 802.11ax Improvements

**Speed improvement**:
- 802.11ac: 1.3 Gbps
- 802.11ax: **9.6 GBPS, 7.4X FASTER** ✓
- Real-world: **2-4 GBPS TYPICAL** ✓

**Technology gains**:
- OFDMA: **DIVIDE CHANNEL INTO SUB-CHANNELS** ✓
- MU-MIMO: **MULTIPLE USERS SIMULTANEOUSLY** ✓
- Spatial streams: **UP TO 8+** ✓

### OFDMA (Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access)

**Purpose**: **EFFICIENT SPECTRUM UTILIZATION** ✓

**Traditional** (802.11ac):
- Channel: One client uses entire 80 MHz
- Others: Wait for turn
- Efficiency: **POOR IF MANY CLIENTS** ⚠️

**OFDMA** (802.11ax):
- Channel: **DIVIDED INTO SUB-CHANNELS** ✓
- Clients: **MULTIPLE GET PORTIONS SIMULTANEOUSLY** ✓
- Efficiency: **BETTER SPECTRUM USAGE** ✓

### MU-MIMO in 802.11ax

**Multi-user MIMO**:
- 802.11ac limit: **ONE CLIENT AT A TIME** ⚠️
- 802.11ax: **MULTIPLE CLIENTS SIMULTANEOUSLY** ✓
- Result: **HIGHER TOTAL THROUGHPUT** ✓

**Example**:
- Scenario: 4 clients downloading
- 802.11ac: Serve one client at 325 Mbps each (rotates)
- 802.11ax: **ALL 4 SIMULTANEOUSLY, SHARED** ✓

### Target Wait Time (TWT)

**Purpose**: **ALLOW DEVICES TO SLEEP MORE** ✓

**Traditional WiFi**:
- Client: Always listening for packets
- Power: **BATTERY DRAINS FAST** ⚠️
- Latency: Low

**TWT** (802.11ax):
- Scheduling: **AP TELLS WHEN TO WAKE** ✓
- Power: **DRAMATIC BATTERY SAVINGS** ✓
- Latency: **SLIGHT INCREASE** ✓

### Dual-Band Advantage (802.11ax)

**802.11ac** (5 GHz only):
- Old device (802.11g): **WON'T CONNECT** ⚠️
- Solution: **SEPARATE AP NEEDED** ⚠️

**802.11ax** (2.4 + 5 GHz):
- Old device (802.11g): **CONNECTS AT 2.4 GHZ** ✓
- New device (WiFi 6): **CONNECTS AT 5 GHZ** ✓
- Benefit: **ONE AP SUPPORTS ALL** ✓

### 802.11ax Channel Widths

**5 GHz channels**:
- 20 MHz: **BASELINE** ✓
- 40 MHz: **TWO 20 MHZ COMBINED** ✓
- 80 MHz: **FOUR 20 MHZ COMBINED** ✓
- 160 MHz: **EIGHT 20 MHZ COMBINED** ✓

**Wider channels**:
- Benefit: **HIGHER THROUGHPUT** ✓
- Drawback: **FEWER TOTAL CHANNELS AVAILABLE** ⚠️

## PART 3: 802.11BE (WiFi 7)

### 802.11be Overview

**Standard year**: **2024, EMERGING** ✓
**Marketing name**: **WIFI 7** ✓
**Frequency**: **2.4 GHZ, 5 GHZ, AND 6 GHZ** ✓
**Technology**: **HIGHER MIMO, WIDER CHANNELS** ✓
**Maximum speed**: **46 GBPS THEORETICAL** ✓

### 802.11be Improvements

**Speed progression**:
- 802.11ac: 1.3 Gbps
- 802.11ax: 9.6 Gbps
- 802.11be: **46 GBPS, 4.8X FASTER THAN 11AX** ✓

**New features**:
- 6 GHz support: **ADDITIONAL SPECTRUM** ✓
- Wider channels: **UP TO 320 MHZ** ✓
- Spatial streams: **12+ POSSIBLE** ✓

### 6 GHz Spectrum (802.11be)

**New band**: **6 GHZ FREQUENCY RANGE** ✓
**Channels**: **MANY MORE THAN 5 GHZ** ✓
**Benefits**:
- Congestion: **VERY LOW, NEW BAND** ✓
- Speed: **MAXIMUM THEORETICAL CAPACITY** ✓
- Devices: **WIFI 6E, WIFI 7 ONLY** ✓

**Timeline**:
- FCC approval: 2020
- Devices available: **2021+** ✓

### Multi-Link Operation (802.11be)

**Purpose**: **SIMULTANEOUSLY USE MULTIPLE BANDS** ✓

**Example**:
- Device connected: 5 GHz + 6 GHz simultaneously
- Benefit: **COMBINED THROUGHPUT** ✓
- Use: **VIDEO, LARGE FILE TRANSFER** ✓

## PART 4: DEPLOYMENT DECISIONS

### Choosing WiFi Standard

**Scenario A** - Budget deployment:
- Budget: $15,000, 5,000 sq ft office
- Standard: **802.11N OR 11AC** ✓
- Reason: **COST-EFFECTIVE, ADEQUATE** ✓

**Scenario B** - High-performance campus:
- Requirement: 1+ Gbps per user
- Devices: Mix old and new
- Standard: **802.11AX FOR FLEXIBILITY** ✓

### 802.11ax vs 802.11ac Comparison

**Metric: Speed**
- 802.11ac: **1.3 GBPS THEORETICAL** ✓
- 802.11ax: **9.6 GBPS THEORETICAL** ✓

**Metric: Bands**
- 802.11ac: **5 GHZ ONLY** ✓
- 802.11ax: **2.4 + 5 GHZ** ✓

**Metric: MU-MIMO**
- 802.11ac: **ONE CLIENT AT TIME** ⚠️
- 802.11ax: **MULTIPLE SIMULTANEOUSLY** ✓

### Migration Path

**Timeline**:
- Keep 11ac: **5+ YEAR LIFESPAN** ✓
- Upgrade to 11ax: **WHEN BUDGET ALLOWS** ✓
- Later to 11be: **WHEN DEVICES AVAILABLE** ✓

### Real-World Expectations

**Theoretical vs real**:
- 802.11ac theoretical: 1.3 Gbps
- 802.11ac real: **400-600 MBPS TYPICAL** ✓
- Factor: **OVERHEAD, COLLISIONS, DISTANCE** ✓

**802.11ax real**:
- Theoretical: 9.6 Gbps
- Real: **2-3 GBPS TYPICAL** ✓
- Benefit: **BETTER THAN 11AC, MULTIPLE USERS** ✓

## PART 5: DEPLOYMENT SCENARIOS

### Stadium WiFi Deployment

**Challenge**: 50,000 concurrent users

**Solution**:
- Standard: **802.11AX MINIMUM** ✓
- AP density: **VERY HIGH, 1 PER 1000 SQ FT** ✓
- Bands: **ALL THREE: 2.4/5/6 GHZ** ✓
- Controller: **CENTRALIZED MANAGEMENT** ✓

### Healthcare Facility WiFi

**Requirements**:
- Reliability: **CRITICAL, MEDICAL DEVICES** ✓
- Latency: **LOW, REAL-TIME REQUIREMENTS** ✓
- Coverage: **UNINTERRUPTED** ✓

**Standard**: 802.11ax with redundancy
- Dual APs: Every location ✓
- Handoff: **SMOOTH, LOW LATENCY** ✓

### Home WiFi Decision

**Family has**:
- 4K TV (WiFi 5 capable)
- Laptops (WiFi 6 capable)
- Smart home (WiFi 4)
- Budget: $150

**Recommendation**: **WIFI 6 ROUTER** ✓
- Reason: **SUPPORTS ALL, FUTURE-PROOF** ✓

### Enterprise Network Upgrade

**Current**: 50 802.11ac APs, 2000 devices

**Upgrade plan**:
- Phase 1 (Year 1): **ADD WIFI 6 IN CORE AREAS** ✓
- Phase 2 (Year 2): **REPLACE ALL WITH 11AX** ✓
- Cost: **$150K+ EQUIPMENT/INSTALL** ✓

## PART 6: TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS

### Data Rates Summary

**802.11n**: **600 MBPS, 40 MHZ** ✓
**802.11ac**: **1.3 GBPS, 80 MHZ** ✓
**802.11ax**: **9.6 GBPS, 160 MHZ** ✓
**802.11be**: **46 GBPS, 320 MHZ** ✓

### Spectrum Efficiency

**Modulation progression**:
- BPSK (802.11b): **1 BIT PER SYMBOL** ✓
- 16-QAM (802.11a): **4 BITS PER SYMBOL** ✓
- 256-QAM (802.11ac): **8 BITS PER SYMBOL** ✓
- 1024-QAM (802.11ax): **10 BITS PER SYMBOL** ✓

### Backward Compatibility Chain

**Device types**:
- 802.11a: **CONNECTS TO 5 GHZ ONLY** ✓
- 802.11n: **CONNECTS 2.4/5 GHZ** ✓
- 802.11ac: **CONNECTS 5 GHZ ONLY, FASTER** ✓
- 802.11ax: **CONNECTS ALL BANDS** ✓

### Planning Checklist

**Before deployment decide**:
- Standard: **SELECT 11AX OR 11BE** ✓
- Coverage: **AP COUNT FOR AREA** ✓
- Bands: **2.4/5/6 GHZ MIX** ✓
- Channels: **PLAN NON-OVERLAPPING** ✓
- PoE budget: **POWER FOR APS** ✓
- Controller: **CENTRALIZED OR STANDALONE** ✓
hints: 802.11ac = WiFi 5 (1.3 Gbps, 5 GHz only); 802.11ax = WiFi 6 (9.6 Gbps, 2.4+5 GHz); 802.11be = WiFi 7 (46 Gbps, 2.4+5+6 GHz)
OFDMA (802.11ax) divides channel into sub-channels; multiple clients get portions simultaneously (better efficiency)
MU-MIMO: 802.11ac serves one client; 802.11ax serves multiple clients simultaneously (higher throughput)
Target Wait Time (TWT) allows devices to sleep, saving battery; key advantage of WiFi 6
Real-world vs theoretical: 802.11ac ~400-600 Mbps (vs 1.3 Gbps); 802.11ax ~2-3 Gbps (vs 9.6 Gbps)
6 GHz spectrum (WiFi 6E/7): New band with many more channels; very low congestion; future-proof
Backward compatibility: 802.11ax supports all bands (2.4/5 GHz); 802.11ac 5 GHz only (no backward compat)
Channel bonding: 802.11ac uses 80 MHz; 802.11ax up to 160 MHz; 802.11be up to 320 MHz
Deployment: WiFi 6 (802.11ax) recommended for enterprises; dual-band supports legacy devices
Real-world overhead: MAC, collision, distance, interference; expect 30-50% of theoretical speed

testCases.assert: assert ('802.11ac' in solution.lower() or 'wifi.5' in solution.lower() or '1.3' in solution.lower())
assert ('802.11ax' in solution.lower() or 'wifi.6' in solution.lower() or '9.6' in solution.lower())
assert ('802.11be' in solution.lower() or 'wifi.7' in solution.lower() or '46' in solution.lower())
assert ('ofdma' in solution.lower() or 'sub' in solution.lower() or 'channel' in solution.lower())
assert ('mu' in solution.lower() or 'multi' in solution.lower() or 'simultaneous' in solution.lower())
assert ('twt' in solution.lower() or 'target' in solution.lower() or 'battery' in solution.lower())
assert ('6ghz' in solution.lower() or 'ghz' in solution.lower() or '6e' in solution.lower())
assert ('real' in solution.lower() or 'overhead' in solution.lower() or 'theoretical' in solution.lower())
assert ('backward' in solution.lower() or 'compat' in solution.lower() or 'legacy' in solution.lower())
assert ('deploy' in solution.lower() or 'standard' in solution.lower() or 'coverage' in solution.lower())
